Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that the sulfur dioxide gas release is evidence of mass cremation of new coronavirus victims.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the increase in sulfur emissions is directly linked to the mass cremation of coronavirus victims, without considering alternative explanations.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the data presented in the Twitter thread are not real-time observations of sulfur concentrations above Wuhan but rather computer-model outputs.
Understate: The claim understates the significance of sulfur emissions from human cremation and instead focuses on industrial sources such as coal burning in power plants.
Exist alternative explanation: The presence of the Wuhan Iron & Steel Company in the area suggests an alternative explanation for the high sulfur emissions, unrelated to mass cremation of coronavirus victims.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on a viral Twitter thread and uncritically repeating its content without verifying the accuracy of the information.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the sulfur emissions data from Windy.com and NASA's GEOS-5 model, presenting them as evidence of mass cremation without proper context or validation.
